content.description: Let f be the function given by the <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4131@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for all x > 0. The derivative of f is given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>−</mo> <mi>ln</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43CE@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.
content.question: Find the x-coordinate of the critical point of f. Determine whether this point is a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither for the function f. Justify your answer.

frqParts.text: Find the x-coordinate of the critical point of f. Determine whether this point is a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither for the function f. Justify your answer.

topic.text: 5.4: Using the First Derivative Test to Determine Relative (Local) Extrema

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
